name: Crispy Fried Egg Salad (Yum Kai Dao)
description: Fried eggs with crispy, bubbly edges tossed with a tart, spicy and refreshing dressing. It's my favourite Thai salad EVER!

video.name: Crispy Fried Egg Salad Recipe - Yum Kai Dao
video.description: Fried egg salad is a classic dish from Thailand. The tart and refreshing dressing together with the creamy egg yolks make for an incredible combination that's unlike any other salad. In this recipe you'll also learn how to fry an egg the Thai way; that is with bubbly crispy edges. It's all gluten-free and comes together in less than 30 minutes!

recipeIngredient: ¼  small red or yellow onion (julienned)
2  stalks (celery plus a handful of leaves)
¼  cup roasted peanuts (roughly chopped or lightly crushed)

itemListElement.text: Add the chilies to a mortar and pestle and pound until fine. Add the palm sugar and pound to dissolve into a thick paste. Add the lime juice and fish sauce and stir to combine.
itemListElement.name: Add the chilies to a mortar and pestle and pound until fine. Add the palm sugar and pound to dissolve into a thick paste. Add the lime juice and fish sauce and stir to combine.

itemListElement.text: In a wok or an small non-stick frying pan, add about a quarter inch of oil. Heat the oil over medium high heat until very hot (you can add a little piece of onion as a heat tester, and once it's bubbling excitedly, the oil is ready to go.)
itemListElement.name: In a wok or an small non-stick frying pan, add about a quarter inch of oil. Heat the oil over medium high heat until very hot (you can add a little piece of onion as a heat tester, and once it's bubbling excitedly, the oil is ready to go.)

itemListElement.text: Crack one egg into the oil, and if your oil is hot enough the egg white should start to bubble right away. Use a spoon to baste the top of the egg with oil as it fries, and keep going for about 2 minutes or until the yolk is set and the white is bubbly and browned around the edges.*You don't want the yolk runny for this because we will be cutting the egg into pieces. I like the yolk to be set, but not completely well done. Traditionally it is cooked well done.

I like the yolk to be set, but not completely well done. Traditionally it is cooked well done.

itemListElement.text: Remove the egg from the pan and let it drain on a paper towel lined plate. Repeat with the remaining eggs.
itemListElement.name: Remove the egg from the pan and let it drain on a paper towel lined plate. Repeat with the remaining eggs.

itemListElement.text: Combine all the vegetables in a mixing bowl.
itemListElement.name: Combine all the vegetables in a mixing bowl.

itemListElement.text: Cut the eggs into six wedges, centred around the yolk so that there is a little bit of yolk in every piece.
itemListElement.name: Cut the eggs into six wedges, centred around the yolk so that there is a little bit of yolk in every piece.

itemListElement.text: Add the eggs to the vegetables and pour the dressing over. Toss gently just to mix and plate. Top with roasted peanuts and serve with jasmine rice. Enjoy!

review.reviewBody: Love this one, thai fried eggs are the best!
This recipe was so well balanced and delicious! You are such an amazing cook Pailin. Thank you for blessing us with these simple awesome dishes!
So simple, quick lunch, so good!

This recipe, like many of your recipes, is a regular in our household. My three boys, 14,12, and 10, all love it and frequently request it. To satisfied three growing boys I make sticky rice to have with the salad and eggs. A perfect, easy, and delicious meal.

I’m so glad I tried this!  It’s so perfectly balanced - every ingredient plays its role.  So  unlike the usual American salad I’m used to, where you just throw together whatever greens you have and pour on dressing from a bottle.  My egg-frying technique will need practice.

I have to settle for light brown rather than palm sugar, serranos instead of Thai green chilies, arugula and parsley subbing for cilantro. Even though not the same taste, it’ll still be so so yummy. I just love eggs, they are so versatile!

This is a delicious and terribly easy yum!  I made it for lunch and will make it again very soon. (Tomorrow?)

Pai, are other herbs subbed in (or added to) the cilantro?  I can see this being just as good with mint and Thai basil too.
I just made this for lunch!  So good!!
